seg.output:
Our senate is seeking advice from you on the matter of the censorial judgement, which they call the consistorium. Two sanctions were established two years ago, in order to prevent cases that occur daily from happening in the future; however, due to the increasing wickedness of people, we have achieved nothing, so that they are driven daily by new attempts, whose wickedness cannot be impeded by any obstacle.
The first sanction is this: those who are guilty of divorce must remain silent for at least one year, behave honestly and devoutly, seek permission from the court and not engage in any profitable activity for improvement; those who act contrary to this prohibition must leave our city and country at our mercy and punishment. Here are two declarations on which the senate could not agree.
The first part wants it to be an exception, since no one should be prevented from it by God, and the payment of the city should be left as punishment for disobedience. The other part: since such a light punishment has no effect, the access to second marriages should not be so common; this would be a cause and an incentive for adultery, divorce and fornication. Therefore, since even minors are prevented from marriage due to the disregard of the parents, and so they are not allowed to marry, it should not be allowed to be an exception or remain so, but a fornication, of those who are guilty of divorce and marry against the prohibition.

seg.output: The initial sanction is this: those who bear the guilt of divorce shall remain silent for at least one year, behave honestly and devoutly, and not seek to remarry; those who transgress this prohibition shall be banished from our city and land, yet subject to our grace and punishment. Here are two declarations, upon which the senate could not agree. One part wished it to be considered a marriage still, as no one should be denied what God has given, and that the state's contributions should be the punishment for such disobedience. The other part argued that, as the punishment for adultery is light, it should not be made so easily available, as it would give rise to fornication, divorce and adultery; and that, as even those under age are not allowed to marry without the consent of their parents, those who, having committed adultery, attempt to remarry should not be considered married, but fornicators, whose punishment shall be decided according to our lord's will, and who shall be detained wherever convenient.The magistrates are willing to accept persons and readmit those once excommunicated, so that all may strive for divorce. Therefore, consider what is more divine, that is, less offensive; for we have no word from the Lord in this matter.The later law is that no one shall marry the person with whom he or she has committed adultery, whether or not they bear the guilt of divorce. This statute should be observed so rigorously that those who divorce, or believe themselves to be innocent of any fault, must not be denied marriage, however notorious the adultery may have been.

Posterior Law: No one shall be allowed to marry the person with whom they have committed adultery, they shall bear the guilt of the divorce or not. This rule is to be applied so widely that the divorced, naming their children or sons, assuming that if it does not come to a lawsuit or court case, they shall remain innocent and not bear the guilt of the divorce, should not be denied, even if adultery is notoriously known. Some people think that, in order to avoid anger, one should value the salvation of the church more than that of private individuals. Desiring some to remain firm in accordance with the rule without any breach. Some also, but with the addition that a court has the power to judge according to justice and the nature of the case. Also consider this and write down your opinion and support it with arguments as you can. I do not doubt that Megander also wrote to Leon.
Farewell; there is nothing new among us.
November last.
Your B. H.
To the learned and pious Heinrich Bullinger, his most beloved brother.

Our Senate is seeking advice from you concerning the censorial judgment procedure, which they call consistorium. Two sanctions were instituted two years ago, in which we wanted to take into account the everyday cases we encounter; however, due to the increasing malice of people, we have achieved nothing, so that we are driven by new attempts every day, the malice of which cannot be hindered by any obstacle.
The first sanction is this: those who are guilty of separation shall remain silent for at least one year, behave honestly and piously, be allowed by the court and not commit any acts of improvement; those who do so contrary to the prohibition shall be banished from our city and country, but only at our mercy and punishment. Here are two declarations on which the Senate could not agree.
The first part wants it to be no less considered as a marriage, because no one should be prevented by God, and the payment of the city shall be considered as a punishment for disobedience. The second part: since such a light punishment has no great effect, the access to second marriages must not be so common; this would give cause and occasion for adultery, separation and violation. Therefore, since the youth under the age of consent are also not allowed to marry without the consent of their parents, and if they marry against the prohibition, it should not be a marriage nor remain one, but an adultery, the punishment for which shall be borne by those who are guilty of separation and who marry contrary to the prohibition.

seg.output: The prior sanction is this: those who bear the guilt of divorce should at least remain silent for one year, behave honestly and devoutly, obtain permission from the court and not seek to remarry; however, those who do so against the prohibition shall avoid our city and country, but at our mercy and punishment. Here are two declarations on which the Senate could not agree. One part would not consider it any less a marriage, because no one should be prevented by God, and the payment from the city should be a punishment for disobedience. The other part: since adultery carries such a light punishment, which is not to be increased to deter it, the access to second marriages must not be so common; otherwise, there would be cause and occasion for whoring, divorce and adultery. Therefore, since the youth under years of age are prevented from marrying, even with the consent of their parents, and so if they remarry, it shall not be a marriage, nor remain one, but a whoring, of those who bear the guilt of divorce and remarry against the prohibition. Holding them to our Lord's command, let them be held wherever you please. The magistrates are easily persuaded to accept persons and to admit those once banished again into the city, so that each one may so eagerly desire the divorce. The posterior law is that no one should marry someone with whom they have committed adultery, whether or not they bear the guilt of divorce. This statute would be so widely observed that those who have been divorced may take their whores or bachelors, believing that if it does not come to a lawsuit or trial, they shall not be prevented from marrying, even though adultery is notorious. Therefore, consider what seems more divine, that is, to offend less; for we have no word of the Lord on these things.
